'''Diversity training''' is training provided by an organization, usually with the stated purpose of treating [[diversity]] as an opportunity and promoting the ability of students and workers from a great variety of backgrounds to cooperate productively and make as great a contribution as possible to organizational goals.
Although it is a big business with a profound effect on business, government and education, observers characterize diversity training in very different ways. Its proponents consider it morally right, because it [[respect diversity|respects diversity]]. They also view it as economically sound, because it enables organizations to draw on multiplicities of talents and strengths. Its opponents consider it an oppressive [[ideology|ideological]] re-education tactic, that actually injures the ability of organizations to attain their goals.
==Books== *Peter Wood, ''Diversity: The Invention of A Concept'', ISBN 1893554627 :An historical account and analysis of the concept.
